titleStmt.title: Letter from Annie A. Gray to Eartha M. M. White. November 21, 1931
titleStmt.author: Annie A. Gray

publicationStmt.p: This document was produced as part of the project "Northeast Florida Editing Workshop" at the University of North Florida.

msIdentifier.repository: University of North Florida, Thomas G. Carpenter Library Special Collections and Archives

msContents.summary: A letter from Annie A. Gray written to Eartha M.M. White informing her of the death and upcoming funeral of a mutual acquaintance.

objectDesc.p: Two handwritten pages and envelope with considerable discoloration and some stains.

editorialDecl.p: This file was transcribed and encoded according to the editorial criteria of the project "Northeast Florida Editing Workshop" (nfew.org) at the University of North Florida. Using the various options encoded within <choice> elements, this file enables the viewing of a diplomatic transcription and a regularized reading text.

body.note: The following is the envelope included with the letter.

figure.figDesc: Red 2-cent stamp with George Washington's profile underneath the words "United States Postage"

p.stamp: Mail Early For Christmas Washington, D.C. 4 Nov. 21, 1931 9 - PM

div.p:
Just a line to let you know
that when you get this note,
if you are at home, the funeral
of your friend John M. Waldron
will be going on.

It is real sad, for they
have nothing and the house
is mortgaged up to the top of
the chimney. The church is
standing for the expenses. A
very grand thing after the way
he acted toward them.

They say he is so swollen.
This clipping will tell you a little
account of them. Should the papers

have anything about the funeral
in them, I'll send you a copy.
Did they notify J.E. of his death?
I was there this P.M., Justjust Mrs.
Waldron is so broken up over
the death of J.M. that I could
not go in.

I tell you, it does not pay
to live so far above our neigh-
bors, for we never know to what
we are coming. Hope all are
well.

I shall try to get to the tail
end of the funeral on my way
home from school, Monday.

Rev.Reverend Walter Brooks buried his wife
that Sunday. Love to everybody in
JaxJacksonville .
Write soon.

body.note: The closing salutation of the letter appears to say "I am lovingly, Annie" and has been transcribed this way.

A non-contemporaneous note reads "newsclipping mentioned in letter can be found in folder titled - Bethel Baptist Institutional Church". See: “Obituary of Reverend J. Milton Waldron. November 20, 1931,” North Florida Editorial Workshop, accessed July 19, 2020, https://nfew.claytonmccarl.domains.unf.edu/items/show/40
